candidates.title: update readme
Release v0.4.1
candidates.body:
## Summary
Patch release with documentation improvements for better discoverability and usability.

## Changes

### Documentation
- 📚 Improved crate metadata for better discoverability on crates.io
  - Added explicit documentation URLs
  - Added homepage URLs
  - Updated keywords to include "api-protection" and "redis"
  - Fixed categories (removed incorrect "no-std")

- 📖 Enhanced README files
  - Completely rewrote main README for easier onboarding
  - Added "Choose Your Path" section for quick decision making
  - Added examples in Python and JavaScript
  - Simplified installation instructions
  - Fixed memory usage calculations with accurate breakdown

- 🚀 Added Redis protocol documentation
  - Comprehensive Redis/RESP protocol docs in server README
  - Examples using redis-cli and client libraries

- 🌍 Made tagline language-agnostic
  - Changed from "for Rust applications" to "for any application"
  - Better reflects multi-protocol server support

### No Breaking Changes
This is a documentation-only release with no code changes.

candidates.title: Release v0.4.0
candidates.body:
## Summary
- Release version 0.4.0 with significant new features and improvements

## What's New in v0.4.0

### Features
- Advanced metrics collection and observability for rate limiter insights (#40)
- Redis/RESP protocol support for high-performance rate limiting (#38)
- Comprehensive metrics system with performance monitoring (#36)
- Local Docker build script replacing GitHub workflow (#39)

### Improvements
- Simplified project structure and reduced redundancy (#34)
- Updated documentation to fix broken links and outdated references (#33)
- Added key length limitations and best practices documentation (#35)

### Breaking Changes
- Removed native transport protocol in favor of standardized protocols (#37)

## Release Checklist

- [x] Bumped version to 0.4.0 in all Cargo.toml files
- [x] All tests pass
- [x] All linters pass (clippy, fmt)
- [x] Created git tag v0.4.0

candidates.title: feat: add advanced metrics for rate limiter insights
candidates.body:
## Summary
- Adds comprehensive metrics to provide insights into rate limiter behavior
- Tracks top 100 denied keys to identify problematic clients
- Monitors denial rates and request patterns for operational visibility

## New Metrics

### Top Denied Keys
- `throttlecrab_top_denied_keys{key="...", rank="N"}` - Top 100 keys by denial count
- Efficient HashMap implementation with periodic cleanup
- Key length validation (max 256 chars) prevents DoS attacks

### Denial Rate
- `throttlecrab_denial_rate_percent` - Percentage of requests denied in last 5 minutes
- Rolling window that automatically resets

### Traffic Patterns
- `throttlecrab_requests_per_minute` - Total requests in the last minute
- 60-minute circular buffer for historical data

### Store Performance
- `throttlecrab_cleanup_duration_seconds` - Duration of last cleanup operation
- `throttlecrab_last_cleanup_evicted_keys` - Keys evicted in last cleanup
- `throttlecrab_estimated_memory_bytes` - Estimated memory usage

## Implementation Details

- Added `record_request_with_key()` method to pass key information to metrics
- Updated all transports (HTTP, gRPC, Redis) to use new method
- Comprehensive Prometheus label escaping for security
- Memory-efficient implementation with bounded data structures

## Performance Impact

Benchmarked with 32 threads, 10,000 requests/thread (320,000 total):
- HTTP: 175,479 req/sec (no change)
- gRPC: 165,483 req/sec (no change)
- Redis: 183,096 req/sec (no change)

## Security Improvements

- Proper escaping of all Prometheus label values (quotes, backslashes, newlines, control chars)
- Key length validation prevents memory exhaustion
- Bounded memory usage with automatic cleanup

## Test plan
- [x] All existing tests pass
- [x] New metrics tests added
- [x] Performance benchmarks show no regression
- [x] Manual testing of metrics endpoint

candidates.title: feat: add Redis/RESP protocol support
candidates.body:
## Summary

This PR adds Redis protocol (RESP) support to ThrottleCrab, allowing Redis clients to interact with the rate limiter using native Redis commands.

### Key Features
- Full RESP (Redis Serialization Protocol) parser and serializer
- Custom `THROTTLE` command for rate limiting
- Support for `PING` and `QUIT` commands
- Redis-compatible responses

### Performance
Redis protocol achieves the **highest performance** among all transports:
- **Redis/RESP**: 185,582 req/s (168 μs P50, 249 μs P99)
- **HTTP/JSON**: 173,544 req/s (178 μs P50, 302 μs P99)
- **gRPC**: 161,591 req/s (190 μs P50, 381 μs P99)

### Security Hardening
This implementation includes comprehensive security measures:
- **Buffer overflow protection**: 64KB max buffer per connection
- **Integer overflow protection**: Bounds checking on all size values
- **Stack overflow protection**: Max array nesting depth of 128
- **Input validation**: Size limits on bulk strings (512MB) and arrays (1M elements)
- **Proper error handling**: No `expect()` or `panic\!` in production code

### Usage Example
```python
import redis

# Connect to ThrottleCrab
r = redis.Redis(host='localhost', port=6379)

# Check rate limit
# THROTTLE key max_burst count_per_period period [quantity]
result = r.execute_command('THROTTLE', 'user:123', 10, 100, 60, 1)

# Result: [allowed, limit, remaining, reset_after, retry_after]
# Example: [1, 10, 9, 60, 0]
allowed = result[0] == 1
remaining = result[2]
```

### Testing
- Comprehensive unit tests with test helpers
- Security-focused test suite covering attack vectors
- Integration tests using real Redis client
- All tests passing, no clippy warnings

### Implementation Details
- Actor-based architecture integration
- Shared rate limiter state across all protocols
- Zero-copy parsing where possible
- Async/await with Tokio

## Checklist
- [x] Tests pass
- [x] No clippy warnings
- [x] Security vulnerabilities addressed
- [x] Documentation updated
- [x] Performance benchmarks updated

candidates.title: refactor: remove native transport protocol
candidates.body:
## Summary
- Removed native transport protocol implementation to simplify the codebase
- Updated all related code, tests, benchmarks, examples, and documentation
- The native protocol provided minimal performance benefits compared to HTTP while adding significant complexity

## Changes Made

### Core Changes
- Removed `transport/native.rs` module containing the native binary protocol implementation
- Removed native transport configuration from `config.rs`
- Removed native transport references from `main.rs` and transport module
- Removed `NativeTransport` metric type from metrics enum

### Test and Benchmark Updates
- Renamed `tcp_throughput.rs` benchmark to `http_throughput.rs`
- Updated all benchmark files to remove native protocol code
- Fixed `reqwest::blocking` compilation errors by using async versions
- Updated integration tests to remove native transport tests
- **NEW**: Removed Native variant from Transport enum in integration tests
- **NEW**: Removed NativeConnectionPool and all native protocol implementations from integration tests
- **NEW**: Updated all integration test files to use only HTTP and gRPC transports

### Documentation Updates
- Updated README.md to remove native protocol references
- Updated performance documentation to remove native protocol claims
- Updated Docker documentation and compose files
- Removed native protocol from transport comparison tables
- **NEW**: Updated throttlecrab/README.md to remove Native Binary interfaces mention
- **NEW**: Updated src/types.rs comment to remove Native serialization reference
- **NEW**: Updated tests/README.md to remove Native transport from performance documentation

### Example Updates
- Removed `test_optimized.rs` - entirely dedicated to native protocol testing
- Removed `protocol_demo.rs` - only demonstrated native protocol
- Removed `benchmark_demo.rs` - benchmarked native protocol performance

### Script Updates
- Updated `run-benchmarks.sh` to reference `http_throughput` instead of `tcp_throughput`
- Verified `run-transport-test.sh` already only supports HTTP/gRPC

## Test Results
- All tests pass ✅
- All benchmarks compile and run successfully ✅
- No clippy warnings ✅
- Code is properly formatted ✅
- No remaining references to native transport (except in git history and one unrelated comment) ✅

## Breaking Changes
This is a breaking change for users relying on the native transport protocol. They will need to switch to either HTTP or gRPC protocols.

## Complete File List of Changes
- Removed: `src/transport/native.rs`
- Removed: `examples/test_optimized.rs`
- Removed: `examples/protocol_demo.rs`
- Removed: `examples/benchmark_demo.rs`
- Modified: `src/config.rs`, `src/main.rs`, `src/transport/mod.rs`, `src/metrics.rs`, `src/types.rs`
- Modified: `benches/` - all benchmark files
- Modified: `tests/integration/` - all integration test files
- Modified: Multiple documentation files

candidates.title: Release v0.3.0
candidates.body:
## Summary

This release includes significant improvements to the rate limiter and removes client timestamps from all protocols.

## Major Changes

### Breaking Changes
- **Removed client timestamps from all protocols** (HTTP, gRPC, Native) - server now always uses its own timestamps
- Simplified API by removing timestamp parameters from client requests

### Bug Fixes
- **Fixed remaining token count calculation** that was always showing full capacity
- Corrected the TAT (Theoretical Arrival Time) distance calculation in rate limiter
- Added division by zero protection in remaining count calculation

### Improvements
- Added comprehensive test coverage for quantity variations and token replenishment scenarios
- Added tests for edge cases including zero quantity, negative quantity, and burst limit handling
- Added tests for fractional token accumulation and time jitter handling

## Changelog

See [CHANGELOG.md](CHANGELOG.md) for detailed changes.

## Migration Guide

If you were passing timestamps in your requests, simply remove them:

### Before (v0.2.x)
```json
{
  "key": "user:123",
  "max_burst": 10,
  "count_per_period": 100,
  "period": 60,
  "quantity": 1,
  "timestamp": "2024-01-01T00:00:00Z"
}
```

### After (v0.3.0)
```json
{
  "key": "user:123",
  "max_burst": 10,
  "count_per_period": 100,
  "period": 60,
  "quantity": 1
}
```

The server now always uses its own timestamp for all rate limiting decisions.

## Test Plan
- [x] All tests pass (`cargo test --all`)
- [x] Clippy passes (`cargo clippy --all-targets --all-features -- -D warnings`)
- [x] Code is formatted (`cargo fmt --all`)

candidates.title: feat: native multi-arch Docker builds using matrix strategy
candidates.body:
## Summary
- Replace QEMU-based multi-arch builds with native builds using GitHub Actions matrix strategy
- Build each architecture on its native runner for significantly faster builds
- Create unified multi-arch manifest after both builds complete

## Changes
- Use matrix strategy to build AMD64 on `ubuntu-latest` and ARM64 on `ubuntu-24.04-arm64`
- Remove QEMU setup as builds now run natively on each architecture
- Add separate manifest job that creates multi-arch manifests from architecture-specific images
- Each architecture image is tagged with `-amd64` or `-arm64` suffix during build
- Final manifest combines both architectures under the original tag names

## Benefits
- **Much faster builds**: No emulation overhead, each architecture builds natively
- **Better reliability**: Avoids QEMU stability issues
- **Resource efficiency**: Each runner uses its native architecture optimally
- **Same user experience**: Users can still pull images without specifying architecture

## Test plan
- [x] Workflow syntax is valid
- [ ] AMD64 builds successfully on ubuntu-latest
- [ ] ARM64 builds successfully on ubuntu-24.04-arm64
- [ ] Multi-arch manifest is created correctly
- [ ] Users can pull images on both architectures

candidates.title: Remove MessagePack protocol support
candidates.body:
## Summary

This PR removes MessagePack protocol support from throttlecrab, simplifying the codebase while keeping the most popular and performant protocols.

## Changes

- Removed MessagePack transport implementation files
- Removed `rmp-serde` dependency from all crates
- Updated CLI to remove MessagePack-related arguments  
- Updated all documentation to remove MessagePack references
- Converted benchmarks and examples to use native protocol instead
- Updated integration tests to support only HTTP, gRPC, and Native

## Rationale

MessagePack was the slowest protocol based on our benchmarks:
- **MessagePack**: 146K req/s 
- **gRPC**: 163K req/s
- **HTTP**: 173K req/s (only 6% slower than native\!)
- **Native**: 183K req/s

Since HTTP is far more popular and nearly as fast as the native protocol, and MessagePack offered no significant advantages, removing it simplifies maintenance and reduces dependencies.

## Remaining Protocols

The server now supports 3 protocols:
1. **Native Binary** - Highest performance for internal services
2. **HTTP/JSON** - Best for general integration, excellent performance
3. **gRPC** - Good for service mesh and type-safe clients

## Testing

- ✅ All tests pass
- ✅ All benchmarks updated and working
- ✅ Examples updated to use native protocol
- ✅ No clippy warnings

candidates.title: Documentation cleanup and enhancement
candidates.body:
## Summary

This PR enhances the project documentation and removes the experimental throttlecrab-client crate.

### Changes Made:

1. **Documentation Updates:**
   - Improved README with better examples and clearer explanations
   - Added comprehensive performance section with benchmark insights
   - Enhanced API documentation with better code examples
   - Added practical client integration examples

2. **Removed throttlecrab-client crate:**
   - The native client didn't achieve the expected performance improvements over HTTP
   - Removed all client-related code and documentation
   - Updated README to recommend using established HTTP clients like `reqwest` which provide:
     - Robust connection pooling and management
     - Automatic retry mechanisms
     - Proper timeout handling
     - Well-tested production stability

3. **Code Quality:**
   - All tests pass
   - Code is properly formatted with `cargo fmt`
   - No clippy warnings

### Rationale

After extensive testing, we found that the native binary protocol client couldn't significantly outperform well-established HTTP clients like `reqwest`. Given the additional maintenance burden and the excellent performance of HTTP (only ~6% slower than native), it makes more sense to recommend using mature HTTP clients that already handle connection management, retries, and error handling properly.

### Testing

- ✅ All unit tests pass
- ✅ All integration tests pass
- ✅ Clippy reports no warnings
- ✅ Code is properly formatted

candidates.title: Add connection pooling and integration tests for massive performance improvements
candidates.body:
## Summary

This PR introduces significant performance improvements through connection pooling and adds comprehensive integration testing infrastructure for ThrottleCrab.

### Key Changes

1. **Connection Pooling Implementation**
   - HTTP: Leverages reqwest's built-in connection pooling
   - gRPC: Removed mutex contention by making clients cloneable
   - MessagePack/Native: Custom connection pools with health checks
   - Added configurable pool parameters and error handling

2. **Integration Test Infrastructure**
   - Created separate `integration-tests` project
   - Multi-transport performance testing framework
   - Automated test scripts with server lifecycle management
   - Support for all transports (HTTP, gRPC, MessagePack, Native)

3. **Native Protocol Fixes**
   - Fixed critical response size bug (34 bytes, not 33)
   - Resolved connection handling issues
   - Added proper error response flushing
   - Updated protocol documentation

### Performance Improvements

Before (connection per request):
- ~500 RPS across all transports

After (with connection pooling):
- **Native: 161,318 RPS** (322x improvement)
- **HTTP: 156,923 RPS** (314x improvement)
- **gRPC: 140,328 RPS** (281x improvement)
- **MessagePack: 111,944 RPS** (224x improvement)

All transports now achieve 100% success rate with stable performance.

### Test Infrastructure

New testing capabilities:
- `run-transport-test.sh` - Test individual or all transports
- `run-heavy-test.sh` - High-load testing (1M requests)
- `run-custom-test.sh` - Customizable performance tests
- Workload patterns: steady, burst, ramp, wave
- Detailed latency percentiles (P50, P90, P95, P99, P99.9)

### Usage Examples

```bash
# Test specific transport
./run-transport-test.sh -t grpc -T 32 -r 100000

# Test all transports
./run-transport-test.sh -t all

# Heavy load test
./run-heavy-test.sh
```

### Follow-up Improvements

Based on review feedback, the following improvements could be made in future PRs:
1. Connection pool size limits with semaphore-based control
2. Connection timeout configuration
3. Long-running stability tests
4. Memory leak detection

This PR delivers substantial performance gains and establishes a robust testing framework for continued optimization.

candidates.title: Add environment variables and enhanced CLI arguments support
candidates.body:
## Summary
This PR adds comprehensive environment variable support and enhances the CLI argument structure for throttlecrab-server.

## Key Changes

### CLI Arguments Enhancement
- **No default transport** - Users must explicitly specify at least one transport (--http, --grpc, --msgpack, --native)
- **Multiple transports** - Can run multiple transports simultaneously with individual configuration
- **Store configuration** - Support for periodic, probabilistic, and adaptive stores with specific parameters
- **Generous defaults** - Large capacity defaults (100k entries, 100k buffer size)

### Environment Variables
- All CLI arguments can be configured via environment variables with `THROTTLECRAB_` prefix
- Proper precedence: CLI arguments override environment variables
- Implemented using clap's built-in env support for automatic handling

### Core Library Updates
- Added builder patterns for all store types (PeriodicStore, ProbabilisticStore, AdaptiveStore)
- Made store configuration parameters customizable
- Updated actor system to support different store implementations

## Usage Examples

```bash
# Single transport
throttlecrab-server --msgpack

# Multiple transports with custom configuration
throttlecrab-server --http --http-port 7070 --grpc --grpc-port 7075

# With adaptive store
throttlecrab-server --msgpack --store adaptive --store-min-interval 5

# Using environment variables
THROTTLECRAB_HTTP=true THROTTLECRAB_HTTP_PORT=8080 throttlecrab-server

# CLI overrides env vars
THROTTLECRAB_HTTP_PORT=8080 throttlecrab-server --http --http-port 7070
```

## Breaking Changes
- Removed `--server` flag - transport must be explicitly specified
- Removed demo mode
- Changed default port assignments for consistency

## Testing
- Verified CLI argument parsing works correctly
- Tested environment variable support
- Confirmed CLI arguments properly override environment variables
- All tests pass, code formatted with rustfmt, clippy warnings resolved

candidates.title: Split project into library and server crates
candidates.body:
## Summary
This PR splits the throttlecrab project into two separate crates:
- `throttlecrab` - Pure Rust rate limiting library with zero dependencies
- `throttlecrab-server` - Server binary with all transports (HTTP, gRPC, MessagePack)

## Changes
- Created a Cargo workspace with two member crates
- Moved core rate limiting functionality to the library crate
- Moved all server code, transports, and CLI to the server crate
- Updated all imports to use the new structure
- Added separate README files for each crate
- Updated dependencies to use workspace inheritance for consistent versions

## Benefits
- **Lightweight library**: Users who only need the rate limiting algorithm can use the library without pulling in server dependencies
- **Cleaner separation**: Clear boundary between core functionality and server implementation
- **Better versioning**: Library and server can be versioned independently
- **Reduced compile times**: Library users don't need to compile server dependencies

## Testing
- All existing tests pass
- Both crates build successfully
- Examples and benchmarks have been updated and work correctly
- Code is formatted and passes clippy checks

## Migration
For library users:
```toml
[dependencies]
throttlecrab = "0.1.0"
```

For server users:
```bash
cargo install throttlecrab-server
```

## Note
The `throttlecrab-server` crate name has already been reserved on crates.io with a placeholder v0.0.1 release.

candidates.title: feat: Add HTTP transport layer with Axum
candidates.body:
## Summary

This PR adds HTTP transport support to ThrottleCrab, providing a standard REST API alongside the existing TCP/MsgPack and gRPC transports.

## Changes

### New Features
- **HTTP Transport Layer**: Implemented using Axum web framework for high performance
- **JSON REST API**: Standard HTTP POST endpoint at `/throttle` for rate limiting requests
- **Health Check**: Added `/health` endpoint for monitoring
- **CLI Support**: Added `--http` flag to start server with HTTP transport

### Implementation Details
- Created `src/transport/http.rs` with Axum-based HTTP server
- Request/response models with proper JSON serialization
- Error handling with appropriate HTTP status codes
- Integration with existing actor-based rate limiter

### Dependency Updates
- Updated to latest versions of dependencies:
  - axum: 0.8.4
  - tonic: 0.14.0
  - prost: 0.14.1
  - clap: 4.5.42
- Added tonic-prost for better protobuf integration
- All tests pass with updated dependencies

### Examples & Tests
- Added `examples/http_client.rs` demonstrating HTTP API usage
- Created unit tests for request/response serialization
- All existing tests continue to pass

### Documentation
- Updated README with HTTP API documentation including request/response formats
- Added comprehensive scaling strategy section
- Documented horizontal scaling approach using client-side sharding

## Transport Comparison

| Transport | Use Case | Performance | Ease of Integration |
|-----------|----------|-------------|-------------------|
| TCP + MsgPack | Maximum efficiency | Highest | Requires MsgPack client |
| HTTP + JSON | Standard REST API | Good | Easy - any HTTP client |
| gRPC | Service mesh | High | Requires protobuf |

## API Example

```bash
curl -X POST http://localhost:9090/throttle \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "key": "user:123",
    "max_burst": 10,
    "count_per_period": 100,
    "period": 60,
    "quantity": 1
  }'
```

Response:
```json
{
  "allowed": true,
  "limit": 10,
  "remaining": 9,
  "reset_after": 60,
  "retry_after": 0
}
```

## Testing

- [x] Unit tests added
- [x] Integration tests pass
- [x] Manual testing with example client
- [x] No clippy warnings
- [x] Code formatted with `cargo fmt`
- [x] All tests pass with updated dependencies

candidates.title: Data Structure Optimizations - Multiple High-Performance Store Implementations
candidates.body:
## Summary

This PR implements high-performance data structure optimizations for the rate limiter, providing 15-22x speedups over the baseline implementation.

## Changes Made

### New Store Implementations (4 total)
1. **AdaptiveMemoryStore** (21.6x speedup) - Multi-trigger cleanup with dynamic intervals
2. **OptimizedMemoryStore** (18.2x speedup) - Simple time-based periodic cleanup  
3. **InternedMemoryStore** (15.6x speedup) - String interning for repeated keys
4. **ProbabilisticMemoryStore** (16.8x speedup) - Deterministic pseudo-random cleanup

### Removed Implementations
- **CompactMemoryStore** - Removed due to u32 timestamp overflow issues
- **AmortizedMemoryStore** - Removed due to HashMap iteration order concerns
- Other experimental stores (TimingWheel, BloomFilter, etc.) - Lower performance

### Issues Fixed (from PR review)
- ✅ Removed CompactMemoryStore to eliminate integer overflow risk
- ✅ Removed AmortizedMemoryStore to eliminate non-deterministic cleanup
- ✅ Added overflow protection to InternedMemoryStore ID counter  
- ✅ Removed debug assertions from production code
- ✅ Removed unused cleanup_probability field

## Performance Results

Benchmarks show significant improvements across all access patterns:
- Sequential access: 15-22x faster
- Random access: 14-20x faster  
- Hot key workloads: 16-23x faster
- Sparse access: 13-19x faster

## Recommendations

For production use:
- **Primary**: AdaptiveMemoryStore - Best overall performance and reliability
- **Alternative**: OptimizedMemoryStore - Simple and effective
- **Specialized**: InternedMemoryStore - For workloads with repeated keys

## Test Coverage

- All stores pass comprehensive test suite (34 tests)
- Multiple access pattern benchmarks included
- Edge cases covered (expiration, CAS operations, overflow)

Generated with Claude Code

candidates.title: feat: Add gRPC transport support
candidates.body:
## Summary

This PR adds gRPC transport support to throttlecrab, providing a standard RPC protocol option alongside the existing MessagePack variants.

## Features Added

- **gRPC Server Implementation**: Full gRPC server using the tonic framework
- **Protocol Buffer Schema**: Defined service and message types for the rate limiting API
- **Performance Benchmarks**: Comprehensive benchmarks comparing gRPC with existing transports
- **Auto-detection of protoc**: Build script automatically finds protoc installation
- **Connection Pooling**: Benchmarks use connection pooling to avoid exhaustion

## Performance

Based on benchmark results:
- **Sequential requests**: ~16-17K requests/sec (~60μs per request)
- **Concurrent clients**: Scales to 100K+ requests/sec with proper connection pooling
- **Comparable performance**: gRPC performs competitively with existing binary protocols

## Usage

```bash
# Start gRPC server (requires protoc installed)
throttlecrab --server --grpc

# Or specify custom port
throttlecrab --server --port 9093 --grpc
```

## Dependencies

- Added `tonic` and `prost` for gRPC support
- Requires `protoc` installed (`brew install protobuf` on macOS)

## Testing

- Added unit tests for gRPC transport
- Added gRPC client example (`examples/grpc_client.rs`)
- Extended protocol comparison benchmarks
- Added dedicated gRPC throughput benchmarks

## Benefits

- **Cross-language support**: gRPC clients available in many languages
- **Better tooling**: Protocol buffer tooling and code generation
- **Type safety**: Strong typing through protobuf definitions
- **Future streaming support**: Foundation for potential streaming APIs

candidates.title: Optimize MessagePack serialization and add compact binary protocol
candidates.body:
## Summary

This PR implements comprehensive performance optimizations for both network protocols and the core rate limiter:

### 🚀 Performance Improvements

1. **Memory Store Optimization**: 171x faster with 10,000 keys
   - Standard MemoryStore: 8K req/s → Optimized: 1.38M req/s
   - Deferred cleanup strategy (every 60s vs every operation)
   - Pre-allocated HashMap capacity to avoid rehashing
   - AHash as default hasher for 37% additional speedup

2. **MessagePack Protocol Optimization**
   - Optimized transport with pre-allocated buffers
   - TCP_NODELAY for lower latency
   - Compact binary protocol option for minimal overhead

3. **Core Algorithm Performance**
   - Single key: 25.8M req/s (39 ns/op)
   - 10,000 keys with AHash: 14.9M req/s (67 ns/op)
   - Only 1.7x slowdown with 10K keys vs 100x before\!

## Key Changes

### Memory Store Optimizations
- `OptimizedMemoryStore`: Deferred cleanup + pre-allocation
- `AdaptiveMemoryStore`: Self-tuning cleanup intervals
- `AmortizedMemoryStore`: Spreads cleanup cost evenly
- AHash enabled by default (optional feature)

### Protocol Optimizations
- `OptimizedMsgPackTransport`: Buffer reuse, TCP_NODELAY
- `CompactProtocolTransport`: Fixed-size binary format
- Benchmarks showing protocol performance differences

### Cleanup Strategies
- **Eager** (standard): O(n) every operation - slow
- **Periodic** (optimized): Every 60s or 20% expired - fast
- **Amortized**: Small batches every N ops - consistent latency
- **Adaptive**: Self-tuning based on cleanup effectiveness

## Benchmarks

Comprehensive benchmarks added:
- `core_performance`: Raw rate limiter speed
- `store_shootout`: All store implementations
- `protocol_comparison`: Network protocol performance
- `cleanup_strategies`: Different cleanup approaches

## Examples
- `performance_demo`: Shows 171x improvement
- `protocol_demo`: Compares protocol latencies
- `benchmark_demo`: TCP throughput testing

## Breaking Changes
None - all optimizations are backward compatible. AHash is optional but enabled by default.

## Test plan
- [x] All existing tests pass
- [x] Core performance benchmarks show improvements
- [x] Network protocols work correctly
- [x] Examples demonstrate performance gains
- [x] Test with `--no-default-features` for zero dependencies
- [x] Verify cleanup actually happens (cleanup tests updated)

candidates.title: Fix benchmark protocol to match actual wire format
candidates.body:
## Summary
Fixed the benchmark protocol to match the actual MessagePack wire format used by the server and optimized benchmarks to reuse connections.

## Changes
### Protocol Fixes
- Updated Request/Response structs in benchmarks to match server expectations
- Fixed field names to match protocol: `max_burst`→`burst`, `count_per_period`→`rate`
- Added required `cmd` field (1 = throttle) to requests
- Changed `allowed` field from bool to u8 (0/1)
- Updated README documentation with correct protocol details
- Fixed default port from 7777 to 9090

### Benchmark Optimizations
- Modified all benchmarks to create connections once and reuse them
- Added TCP_NODELAY to reduce latency
- Created connection pool benchmark to test pooled connections
- Fixed multi-threaded benchmarks to maintain persistent connections
- Changed default log level from debug to info to reduce noise

## Performance Results

### Single-threaded Performance
- **~15.6k requests/second** (63.9µs per request)
- Includes full TCP round-trip + MessagePack serialization

### Multi-threaded Scaling
- 2 threads: **~42.8k req/s** (2.7x scaling)
- 4 threads: **~77k req/s** (4.9x scaling)
- 8 threads: **~142.9k req/s** (9.1x scaling)
- 16 threads: **~271.5k req/s** (17.4x scaling)

### Connection Pool Performance
- 8 threads with 16 connection pool: **~193k req/s**
- Pool sizes show consistent ~17k req/s per connection

### Key Insights
1. **Excellent linear scaling** with thread count
2. **No actor contention** - single-threaded actor handles 270k+ req/s
3. **~60µs per request** including all overhead
4. **Competitive with Redis** performance levels

## Test Plan
- [x] Verified benchmark_demo example works
- [x] Ran all benchmarks successfully
- [x] Confirmed server accepts the corrected protocol
- [x] Tested connection pooling scenarios
- [x] Measured performance with reused connections

candidates.title: Pure rate limiter library + MessagePack TCP transport
candidates.body:
## Summary
- Refactored crate into a pure rate limiting library with zero network dependencies
- Implemented MessagePack over TCP transport in the binary
- Removed all system time calls from library - now accepts timestamps as parameters

## Changes

### Library (pure, minimal dependencies)
- **Zero async/network dependencies** - only depends on `thiserror`
- **Synchronous API** - no tokio, no async
- **No system calls** - accepts timestamps as parameters instead of calling `SystemTime::now()`
- **Minimal exports** - only core rate limiting types exposed

### Binary (all network/async code)
- **Actor pattern** - wraps synchronous rate limiter with async interface
- **MessagePack over TCP** - framed protocol with 4-byte length header
- **CLI interface** - server mode and demo mode
- **All dependencies** - tokio, serde, rmp-serde, etc. only in binary

### Benefits
- Library can be used in any context (embedded, WASM, no_std with alloc)
- No system calls = faster and more predictable performance
- Clear separation of concerns
- Zero network attack surface in the library

### Breaking Changes
- `Store` trait methods now require `SystemTime` parameter
- `RateLimiter::rate_limit()` now requires `SystemTime` parameter

## Test Plan
- [x] All library tests pass
- [x] All binary tests pass
- [x] cargo fmt clean
- [x] cargo clippy clean
- [ ] Manual testing of TCP server
- [ ] Performance benchmarks

candidates.title: Add GitHub Actions workflows and CI/CD pipeline
candidates.body:
## Summary
- Added essential GitHub Actions workflows for CI/CD
- Fixed all rustfmt and clippy warnings
- Simplified CI setup with focused workflows
- Switched to MIT license only

## Changes Made

### GitHub Actions Workflows
- **ci.yml**: Code quality checks (rustfmt, clippy, doc generation)
- **test.yml**: Test suite running on Ubuntu with stable Rust
- **security.yml**: Security audits with cargo-audit and cargo-deny
- **dependabot.yml**: Automated dependency updates

### Code Improvements
- Fixed all clippy warnings:
  - Removed redundant closures
  - Added Default implementation for MemoryStore
  - Fixed unused imports
  - Resolved mutable reference issues
- Applied rustfmt to entire codebase
- Fixed nested test module naming conflicts

### Configuration Files Added
- **rustfmt.toml**: Code formatting rules
- **clippy.toml**: Linting configuration
- **deny.toml**: Security and license policies

### Other Changes
- Updated dependencies (thiserror v2, config v0, criterion v0.7)
- Switched from dual MIT/Apache-2.0 to MIT license only
- Added proper #[cfg(test)] attributes to test modules

## Notes
- Simplified CI compared to initial approach - removed complex workflows in favor of essential checks
- All tests pass on stable Rust
- Code is now fully compliant with rustfmt and clippy standards
